case_name: Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj v. Board of Revenue

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 326 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 326 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 10, 1959 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 10 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1959 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Writ Petition No. 10 of 1957.

facts.text: Board of Revenue passed order on November 6, 1956 directing recovery of Matalaba Matmi Rs. 15,404/14/6 from Shebait of appellant temple.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that respondent No. 1, the Board of Revenue, had passed an order on November 6, 1956, directing that the Matalaba Matmi amounting to Rs. 15,404/14/6 be recovered from the Shebait of the appellant temple.

facts.text: Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 10 of 1957 in Rajasthan High Court disputing validity of Board of Revenue order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant disputed the validity of this order and filed a Writ Petition No. 10 of 1957 in the High Court of Rajasthan contending that the said amount was not recoverable from the appellant.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has dismissed this writ petition and the appellant has come to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has dismissed this writ petition and the appellant has come to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Several lands granted to appellant Idol from time to time in name of the Idol.

anchor.surface_text: In its petition, the case for the appellant was that several lands had been granted to the appellant from time to time and that these grants were made in the name of the Idol,

facts.text: Seva Pooja of Idol and management of properties entrusted to Goswami since Idol taken to Jaipur from Brindaban.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Seva Pooja of the Idol and the management of its properties was entrusted to the Goswami ever since the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj was taken to Jaipur from Brindaban.

facts.text: Goswami Shri Krishna Chandra succeeded to Shebaitship in 1888 and continued until 1935.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of the ninth Shebait, Goswami Shri Krishna Chandra succeeded to the Shebaitship in 1888 and continued to be in management as such Shebait until 1935.

facts.text: Goswami Bhola Nath succeeded to Shebaitship on death of Krishna Chandra in 1935 and managed until 1945.

anchor.surface_text: On his death, his eldest son Goswami Bhola Nath succeeded and Seva Pooja was looked after by him during his lifetime. On the death of Goswami Bhola Nath in 1945,

facts.text: Goswami Pradumna Kumar succeeded to Shebaitship in 1945 on death of Bhola Nath and has been managing properties and Seva Pooja.

anchor.surface_text: his eldest son Goswami Pradumna Kumar succeeded to the Shebaitship and has been carrying on the management of the properties of the temple and looking after the Seva Pooja of the Idol.

facts.text: Impugned order passed during management of Pradumna Kumar.

anchor.surface_text: It was during the management of Pradumna Kumar that the impugned order has been passed by respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Matmi sanctioned in favour of Goswami Bhola Nath on death of Krishna Chandra and to Pradumna Kumar on death of Bhola Nath, total Rs. 15,404/14/6.

anchor.surface_text: According to this order, Matmi has been sanctioned in favour of Goswami Bhola Nath on the death of Krishna Chandra Deo and in favour of Pradumna Kumar Deo on the death of Bhola Nath and the total amount directed in that behalf is Rs. 15,404/14/6.

facts.text: Respondents disputed that properties granted to Idol, stated documents regarding original grants not traceable.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the allegation of the appellant that the properties in question had been granted to the Idol, the respondents reply merely, stated that allegation was not admitted as the documents regarding the original grants were not traceable.

facts.text: Prior order dated April 20, 1954 on which November 1956 order based.

anchor.surface_text: as well as the prior order dated April 20, 1954 on which the latter order was based.

facts.text: High Court proceeded on basis that Idol owner of properties.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has proceeded to deal with this dispute on the basis that the appellant, the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj was the owner of the properties.

facts.text: Patta dated 21st Ramzan St. 1123 allotted villages Dehra and Salampukh Balahadi for Punya Bhog of Thakurji Sriji.

anchor.surface_text: The copy of the Patta dated 21st Ramzan St. 1123 Annexure Exbt. 4 shows that the villages Dehra and Salampukh Balahadi in Pargana Hindaun Baseshu Prasad were allotted for Punya Bhog of Thakurji Sriji.

facts.text: Patta dated Katik Badi 8 of Smt. 1808 allotted village Govindpur Bas Hathyod for Bhog of Thakurji Sriji.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the copy of the Patta dated Katik Badi 8 of Smt. 1808 Annexure Exbt. 5 shows that the village Govindpur Bas Hathyod Tehsil Oasaba, Sawai Jaipur was allotted for the Bhog food offerings of Thakurji Sriji.

facts.text: Jaipur Matmi Rules came into force in 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The Jaipur Matmi Rules came into force in 1945 and some of the relevant provisions of these Rules must now be considered

facts.text: Lands granted to appellant resumed by State of Rajasthan by notification No. F. 388 REV/1.A/53 dated Jan. 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: it has been brought to our notice by the appellant that it had made a compensation claim because lands granted to the appellant had been resumed by the State of Rajasthan by notification No. F. 388 REV/1.A/53 dated Jan. 1, 1959

facts.text: State of Rajasthan sanctioned annual sum by way of annuity to Deity under order dated April 24, 1962, deducting Rs. 15,404/14/6 Matmi.

anchor.surface_text: and that an annual sum by way of annuity to the Deity had been sanctioned by the State of Rajasthan under its order dated April 24, 1962. This order has, however, directed that the amount of Rs. 15,404/14/6 which has been ordered by respondent No. 1 to be recovered by way of Matmi should be deducted

facts.text: Supreme Court holds grants made in favour of Idol, not Shebaits.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we feel no difficulty in dealing with the present appeal on the same basis which the High Court has adopted in its judgment. The grants in question were grants made in favour of the Idol and not in favour of the Shebaits.

facts.text: Predecessors of present Shebait applied for Matmi and present Shebait filed application.

anchor.surface_text: In that connection, the High Court referred to the fact that the predecessors of the present Shebait had applied for Matmi and the present Shebait himself had similarly filed an application in that behalf.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition with costs.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court considered the merits of the writ petition filed by the appellant and dismissed it with costs.

facts.text: Appellant averred in para 3 of writ petition that all State grants made to appellant in name of Idol.

anchor.surface_text: We have already noticed that a specific averment was made by the appellant in paragraph 3 of its writ petition that all the State grants made to the appellant from time to time were in the name of the Idol,
rule 5 of the Jaipur Matmi Rules, 1945, the appellant, the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj, is liable to pay the Matmi amount in question.

concepts.interpretation: All State grants subject to Matmi except certain cases; does not apply to grants to Idol as no death of holder or successor.
concepts.unlisted_description: Provides that all State grants shall be subject to Matmi with certain exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 1 defines a State grant as meaning a grant of an interest in land made or recognised by the Ruler of the Jaipur State and includes a jagir, muamla, suba, istimrar, chakoti, badh, bhom, inam, tankha, udak, milak, aloofa, khangi, bhog or other charitable or religious grant,

concepts.interpretation: Includes charitable or religious grants; applies to grants made in favour of the Idol.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: to succeed. Rule 14 deals with the same problem in the absence of a direct male lineal descendant. The proviso to rule 14 lays down, inter alia, that

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 3 refers to Matmi and defines it in these terms Matmi means mutation of the name of the successor to a State grant on the death of the last holder. The person in whose name matmi is sanctioned is called the matmidar

concepts.interpretation: Matmi payable on death of holder and mutation to successor; no application to perpetual Idol as grantee with no death.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 4 defines Nazarana thus Nazrana is the sum payable, in addition to matalba matmi, by an adopted son or by a successor other than a direct male lineal descendant of the last holder.

concepts.interpretation: Shebait's beneficial interest arises from Hindu law/custom, not State grant; hence not subject to Matmi.
concepts.unlisted_description: Under Hindu law, Shebait has beneficial interest per usage/custom, not as trustee or grantee.

concepts.unlisted_description: Government discretion in selecting successor for temple maintenance grants.

issues.text: whether under rule 5 of the Jaipur Matmi Rules, 1945, the appellant, the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj, is liable to pay the Matmi amount in question

anchor.surface_text: The short point of law which arises in this appeal is whether under rule 5 of the Jaipur Matmi Rules, 1945, the appellant, the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj, is liable to pay the Matmi amount in question.

issues.text: can the grant made to the appellant be said to attract the operation of rule 5

anchor.surface_text: With the rest of the Rules we are not concerned in the present appeal. The question which arises is, can the grant made to the appellant be said to attract the operation of rule 5 ? Rule 5 prescribes for the levy of Matmi in respect of State grants

issues.text: whether the appellants estate is liable to pay Matmi under r. 5

anchor.surface_text: In deciding the question as to whether the appellants estate is liable to pay Matmi under r. 5 it is necessary to examine the nature of this Matmi, and find out whether a claim in respect of it can be made against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, took the view that since the Shebaits were managing the properties and performing the Seva Pooja of the appellant Idol, Shebaitship itself being hereditary the relevant Rules applied, because the beneficial interest which the Shebaits held could be said to amount to a State grant within the meaning of r.4 1 .

issues.text: whether a Shebait has some kind of a beneficial interest in the property of the temple, that beneficial interest itself could be treated as a State grant
whether the writ petition had been filed by the Idol ... the grievance made by the Idol was technically not justified since the impugned order had been passed against the Shebait

anchor.surface_text: In that connection, the High Court referred to the fact that the predecessors of the present Shebait had applied for Matmi and the present Shebait himself had similarly filed an application in that behalf. According to the High Court, the plain meaning of the definition of Matmi is that it is payable at the time of the recognition of the succeeding Shebait. In this connection the High Court has also observed that the writ petition had been filed by the Idol and though the Shebait appeared as the agent of the Idol, it was not a petition filed by the Shebait as such, and since the impugned order had been passed against the Shebait, the grievance made by the Idol was technically not justified.

arguments.claim: The properties were granted to the Idol, not the Shebaits, and thus not liable for Matalaba Matmi.

anchor.surface_text: In its petition, the case for the appellant was that several lands had been granted to the appellant from time to time and that these grants were made in the name of the Idol, and that the Seva Pooja of the Idol and the management of its properties was entrusted to the Goswami ever since the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj was taken to Jaipur from Brindaban. On the death of the ninth Shebait, Goswami Shri Krishna Chandra succeeded to the Shebaitship in 1888 and continued to be in management as such Shebait until 1935.

arguments.claim: Matalaba Matmi properly levied against the Shebaits; properties liable.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the allegation of the appellant that the properties in question had been granted to the Idol, the respondents reply merely, stated that allegation was not admitted as the documents regarding the original grants were not traceable. The respondents urged that the Matalaba Matmi had been properly levied by respondent No. 1 against the Shebaits and that the appellants grievance that its properties were not liable to pay the said amount was not well-founded.

arguments.court_reasoning: Documents show grants to Idol; denies liability.

arguments.claim: Shebaits' beneficial interest amounts to a State grant under r.4(1); succession to Shebaitship attracts Matmi under rules.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has proceeded to deal with this dispute on the basis that the appellant, the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj was the owner of the properties. It, however, took the view that since the Shebaits were managing the properties and performing the Seva Pooja of the appellant Idol, Shebaitship itself being hereditary the relevant Rules applied, because the beneficial interest which the Shebaits held could be said to amount to a State grant within the meaning of r.4(1).

arguments.court_reasoning: Beneficial interest derived from Hindu law/custom, not State grant.

arguments.claim: Predecessors and present Shebait applied for Matmi, recognizing succession; Matmi payable on recognition of succeeding Shebait.

anchor.surface_text: On this view, the High Court came to the conclusion that what is contemplated in the Matmi Rules is the succession to a Shebait. In that connection, the High Court referred to the fact that the predecessors of the present Shebait had applied for Matmi and the present Shebait himself had similarly filed an application in that behalf. According to the High Court, the plain meaning of the definition of Matmi is that it is payable at the time of the recognition of the succeeding Shebait.

arguments.claim: Writ petition by Idol technically not justified as order passed against Shebait.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection the High Court has also observed that the writ petition had been filed by the Idol and though the Shebait appeared as the agent of the Idol, it was not a petition filed by the Shebait as such, and since the impugned order had been passed against the Shebait, the grievance made by the Idol was technically not justified.

arguments.claim: Under rule 5 of Jaipur Matmi Rules, 1945, all State grants subject to Matmi; applies to Idol's grants.

anchor.surface_text: The short point of law which arises in this appeal is whether under rule 5 of the Jaipur Matmi Rules, 1945, the appellant, the Idol of Thakurji Shri Govind Deoji Maharaj, is liable to pay the Matmi amount in question. It appears that respondent No. 1, the Board of Revenue, had passed an order on November 6, 1956, directing that the Matalaba Matmi amounting to Rs. 15,404/14/6 be recovered from the Shebait of the appellant temple.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule 5 requires application via definition in r.4(3) which needs death of holder; Idol perpetual.

arguments.claim: Idol is juridical person not subject to death; no successor, hence no Matmi under r.4(3) definition.
Grants made in favor of Idol, not Shebaits; Shebait manages by virtue of Shebaitship, not as grantee.

anchor.surface_text: The copy of the Patta dated 21st Ramzan St. 1123 Annexure Exbt. 4 shows that the villages Dehra and Salampukh Balahadi in Pargana Hindaun Baseshu Prasad were allotted for Punya Bhog of Thakurji Sriji. Similarly, the copy of the Patta dated Katik Badi 8 of Smt. 1808 Annexure Exbt. 5 shows that the village Govindpur Bas Hathyod Tehsil Oasaba, Sawai Jaipur was allotted for the Bhog food offerings of Thakurji Sriji.

arguments.claim: Not all properties of appellant before court; may not all be granted to Idol.
arguments.court_reasoning: Specific averment in petition; proceeded on basis Idol grantee; respondents did not deny effectively.

arguments.claim: Shebait's beneficial interest not a State grant; derived from Hindu law/custom, not State.
Relief only by moving govt under r.20(xvii) for exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Modi J. also held that it was not possible for the Court to help the appellant in view of the Rules as they stand. He thought that the only relief which the appellant can secure is by moving respondent No. 3 to exercise its discretion under clause xvii of r.20 and get exemption from the payment of the amount in question.

holdings.text: The grants in question were grants made in favour of the Idol and not in favour of the Shebaits.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we feel no difficulty in dealing with the. present appeal on the same basis which the High Court has adopted in its judgment. The grants in question were grants made in favour of the Idol and not in favour of the Shebaits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pattas explicitly allot lands for Bhog/Punya Bhog of Thakurji Sriji; High Court proceeded on same basis; respondents did not effectively deny.

holdings.text: An Idol which is a juridical person is not subject to death; no question of successor or Matmi mutation under r.4(3).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual definition of Matmi in r.4(3) requires death of holder and mutation to successor; Idol perpetual under Hindu law.

holdings.text: No amount can be recovered from the properties belonging to the Idol on the ground that Matmi is claimable against a successor Shebait.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from no death/successor for Idol; Matmi claim cannot attach to Idol's properties via Shebait succession.

holdings.text: The beneficial interest of the Shebaits does not amount to a State grant under r.4(1); derived from Hindu law/custom/usage, not State grant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing precedents (Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji, Vidya Varuthi); Shebait's usufruct per custom, not vesting from State.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in holding that the beneficial interest of the Shebaits amounted to a State grant, making the impugned order valid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it seems to us that the High Court was in error in holding that the beneficial interest of the Shebaits in the properties granted to the appellant amounted to a State grant, and so, the impugned order was perfectly valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's interpretation; beneficial interest not from State grant.

holdings.text: Properties granted to appellant constitute State grants under r.4(1) but do not become liable to pay Matmi dues under r.4(3); writ prayer 16(1) allowed restraining recovery from estate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines r.4(1) inclusion with r.4(3) requirement unmet; justifies writ relief for estate protection.

holdings.text: No opinion expressed on validity of impugned order against present Shebait or prayer 16(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not necessary for decision; court not concerned with order against Shebait.

In almost every case, said Mr. Justice Ameer Ali, the Mahant is given the right to a part of the usufruct, the mode of  1  1964 1 S.C.R. 561.  2  48 I.A. 392,

precedents.case_name: Vidya Varuthi Thirtha Swamigal v. Balusami Ayyar
precedents.cited_proposition: Shebait or Mahant has beneficial interest in usufruct depending on usage and custom, not vested as property, answerable as trustee for mal-administration
precedents.cited_holding: In almost every case, said Mr. Justice Ameer Ali, the Mahant is given the right to a part of the usufruct, the mode of enjoyment and the amount of the usufruct depending again on usage and custom. In numbercase was the property companyveyed to or vested in him, number is he a trustee in the English sense of the term, though in view of the obligations and duties resting on him, he is answerable as a trustee in the general sense for mal-administration.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, prayer made by the appellant in paragraph 16 1 of its writ petition must be allowed. outcome.relief_summary: Prayer in paragraph 16(1) of writ petition allowed (restraining recovery of Matmi from appellant's estate); no opinion on prayer in paragraph 16(2) (quashing impugned order)
